statement:
Throughout this entry, $\omega$, $\tau$, and $\Omega$ denote the number
of distinct prime factors function, the divisor function, and the ,
respectively.

For any positive integer $n$,
$2^{\omega(n)} \le \tau(n) \le 2^{\Omega(n)}$.

Note that $2^{\omega(n)}$, $\tau(n)$, and $2^{\Omega(n)}$ are
multiplicative. Also note that, for any positive integer $n$, the
numbers $2^{\omega(n)}$, $\tau(n)$, and $2^{\Omega(n)}$ are positive
integers. Therefore, it will suffice to prove the inequality for prime
powers.

Let $p$ be a prime and $k$ be a positive integer. Thus:

$\begin{array}{rl}
\displaystyle 2^{\omega(p^k)} & =2 \\
\\
\tau(p^k) & =k+1 \\
\\
\displaystyle 2^{\Omega(p^k)} & = 2^k \end{array}$

Hence, $2^{\omega(p^k)} \le \tau(p^k) \le 2^{\Omega(p^k)}$. It follows
that $2^{\omega(n)} \le \tau(n) \le 2^{\Omega(n)}$.

This theorem has an obvious corollary.

For any squarefree positive integer $n$,
$2^{\omega(n)}=\tau(n)=2^{\Omega(n)}$.
